newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: US to seek WTO panel against Japan in Kodak case.
newsitem.headline: US to seek WTO panel against Japan in Kodak case.

text.p: The United States on Friday asked the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to set up a dispute settlement panel to investigate Eastman Kodak Co's allegations of anti-competitive practices by Japan and its giant Fuji Photo Film Co, trade sources said.
Neither U.S. nor Japanese trade officials in Geneva could be reached immediately for comment on Friday evening.
A WTO spokesman confirmed that U.S. trade officials in Geneva had filed a request for a dispute panel late on Friday, but he had no details on the complaint.
A special meeting of the WTO Dispute Settlement Body is to be held on October 3 to consider the U.S. request, he added.
"The United States has requested a panel against Japan concerning the Kodak-Fuji dispute," a WTO spokesman told Reuters. "It was in the goods dispute case.
"The U.S. also submitted a request for further consultations on the dispute involving the services aspect of the case," he added.
Washington last June said it would investigate alleged Japanese market barriers to photo film and paper which discriminate against treatment of imported goods.
Then-U.S. Trade Representative Mickey Kantor acted on a petition by American photography giant Eastman Kodak which charged anti-competitive practices by Japan and Fuji.
Kodak at the time said Japanese market barriers have cost it an estimated $5.6 billion in lost sales since the mid-1970s.
Kantor's office said that, according to Kodak's petition, Fuji enjoys a 75 percent share of the Japanese market for photographic film, while Kodak's share is ony seven percent.

Kodak's petition cited decades of exclusionary practices, largely involving Fuji, including price-fixing in trade associations and trying to control financially struggling wholesalers and retailers through cash payments to them.

WTO director-general Renato Ruggiero, who will attend the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Washington next week, will meet U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky on Monday, a WTO spokesman told a regular news briefing earlier in the day.
